title: I deological sympathy with communism helped cause the greatest spy scandal in British history, the case of the Soviet spies Guy Burgess

note: the eminent art historian Anthony Blunt (1907–83), was not publicly outed until
title: The three, all Cambridge men and referred to collectively as the Cambridge Spies, passed on an enormous amount of information to the Soviet intelligence service, the KGB, in World War II and the early cold war. Burgess and Maclean defected to the Soviet Union in 1951, but Philby managed to keep his true loyalties secret for longer and only defected in
The mysterious “fourth man

by which point he had been appointed Master of the Queen’s Pictures. The scandal was a huge embarrassment for the British intelligence community, and it impaired cooperation with U.S. intelligence agencies for decades. The Cambridge Spies have remained a source of fascination and numerous works of art and historical investigation for decades

Scottish Calvinists rebel against the new Anglican liturgy introduced by King Charles I. 1639–1640 Bishop’s Wars between King Charles I and the Scottish rebels end with Scottish occupation of part of northern England
Irish rebellion
Irish rebels defeated by Oliver Cromwell
Republican government overthrown, replaced by military-based rule of Oliver Cromwell
Chartering of the Royal Society, Britain’s preeminent scientific organization
Last great outbreak of the plague in Britain, centering in London
Great Fire of London
Publication of Isaac Newton’s Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy
Revolution overthrows James II; he is succeeded by William of Orange and Mary. Industry and Conquest 1701–1713 War of the Spanish Succession
Parliamentary union of England and Scotland leads to the creation of the United Kingdom of Great Britain
Death of Anne, the last Stuart monarch, followed by the accession of the House of Hanover with the reign of George I
Jacobite rising to restore the Stuarts is defeated
The last Jacobite rising defeated
Seven Years’ War sees overwhelming British victory, driving the French from Canada and establishing Britain as the world’s premier naval and colonial power
Treaty of Paris ends the American Revolution with the loss of most British colonies in North America
The war between Britain and revolutionary France begins
1801 Act of Union between Great Britain and Ireland creates the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
Britain in the Age of Empire 1851 Great Exhibition, the first World’s Fair, opens in the Crystal Palace in London
Publication of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species, setting forth his theory of evolution by natural selection
Second Reform Bill further broadens the right to vote
Married Women’s Separate Property Act allows married women to hold property independently of their husbands
Third Reform Bill further broadens the parliamentary franchise
The Boer War ends in British victory but reveals British weaknesses and adds to British global unpopularity
Formation of the Labour Representation Committee, later to be known as the Labour Party
Entente Cordiale, an alliance between Britain and France
Anglo-Russian Entente
Drastic limitations imposed on the power of the House of Lords
Fourth Reform Bill gives the parliamentary vote to men over the age of 21 and women over 30
The Irish Free State is constituted as a dominion of the Crown
Chartering of the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC
Women get the right to vote on the same basis as men
Statute of Westminster loosens the colonies of settlement from British rule by establishing the legislative independence of the dominions
Munich agreement

publisher: Fall of France. Battle of Britain
title: Chamberlain government overturned to give way to Churchill coalition government
Germany invades the Soviet Union. Japan enters the war with attacks on Britain and the United States. Germany declares war on the United States
Fall of Singapore to the Japanese. British victory over the Germans in North Africa at the Battle of El Alamein
British forces capture Tripoli from the Italians. Allied invasion of Sicily followed by invasion of Italy
British and Indian troops win victory over the Japanese at Imphal
End of World War II with Allied victory

General election returns the Labour Party, headed by Clement Atlee. Between 1945 and 1951 the Labour government transforms the British economy with a program of nationalizations and lays the foundations of the British welfare state
Iron Curtain” speech by Winston Churchill
India and Pakistan win their independence from Britain, while remaining members of the Commonwealth
Britain leaves Palestine
Britain participates in the Korean War as a member of the United Nations
Festival of Britain on the 100th anniversary of the Great Exhibition
Coronation of Elizabeth II
The Suez Crisis leads to fall of Anthony Eden as prime minister
Founding of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament (CND

The British attempt to enter the Common Market (founded in 1957) is vetoed by the French. Prime Minister Harold Macmillan’s “Winds of Change” speech signals British acceptance of its African colonies’ moves to independence
South Africa becomes an independent republic
Formation of the Beatles
The Beatles tour America
Beginning of the Troubles in Northern Ireland
Britain enters the European Common Market
Margaret Thatcher becomes prime minister
The Falklands War
Irish Republican Army bombs the hotel in Brighton hosting the Conservative Party Conference

note: John Major takes over as prime minister and leader of the Conservative Party.
title: Faced with opposition from within the Conservative Party, Margaret Thatcher withdraws from leadership
Britain fights as a U.S. ally in the Gulf War

publisher: Handover of Hong Kong to China
title: Major government comes to an end as New Labour under Tony Blair wins an overwhelming victory in the parliamentary elections
Establishment of the Scottish parliament. Good Friday Agreement, or Belfast Agreement, ends Irish Troubles
Establishment of the Welsh national assembly. House of Lords Act removes most of the hereditary element from the upper chamber of Parliament
Millennium Dome opened
Britain joins the United States in the Iraq War
Terrorist bombings in London by Muslim radicals
Resignation of Tony Blair as leader of the Labour Party and prime minister; succeeded by
British financial institution Northern Rock taken under government control, as concern grows about financial crisis
British troops withdrawn from Iraq. European Parliament elections return two members of the British National Party, the BNP’s first victory in a national election
